The Dobbie-Castonguay Parliamentary Committee recommended recognizing Quebec as a distinct society, entrenching Indigenous self-government in Canada’s constitution, including a “Canada clause” in the constitution elaborating on values such as egalitarianism and diversity and senate reform (McConnell 2006). The Dobbie-Beaudoin Committee also recommended recognizing Quebec as a distinct society and senate reform but recommended a Quebec veto on all constitutional changes (McConnell 2006). Both these reports formed the basis of negotiations between the federal, provincial, and territorial governments and representatives of Aboriginal peoples which eventually resulted in Charlottetown Accord (Gall Charlottetown 2006a).

The Charlottetown Accord included proposals on five main topics. First, the Accord proposed adding in a new “Canada clause” in the constitution that would express fundamental Canadian values and guide courts in their interpretation of the constitution (Charlottetown Accord 1992). The values listed included recognizing Quebec as a distinct society within Canada that includes a French-speaking majority, a unique culture, and civil law tradition; a commitment of Canadians and their governments to the vitality and the development of official language minorities throughout Canada; and recognizing that the governments of Aboriginal peoples of Canada constitute one of the three orders of government in the country (Charlottetown Accord 1992).

Second, the Accord proposed a number of major reforms to Canada’s legislative and judicial institutions. Canada’s Senate would be reformed for one. Each province would have an equal number of senators who would have to be elected either by the province’s legislature or by general election in each province and exercise effective powers representative of the provinces and issues (Charlottetown Accord 1992). The Accord also proposed entrenching all matters relating to the Supreme Court into the constitution subject to unanimous approval, except for the nomination and appointment process of Supreme Court judges, which under the Accord would require approval under the general constitutional 7/50 amending formula (Charlottetown Accord 1992). Changes were also proposed to the House of Commons. Quebec would be guaranteed 25% of the seats in the House of Commons and otherwise the composition of the House of Commons would be adjusted to better reflect representation by population increasing the number of seats allotted to Ontario, British Columbia, and Alberta (Charlottetown Accord 1992).

Third, the Accord also proposed adding a provision in the constitution that would require the federal government to provide “reasonable compensation” to any province that opted not to participate in a Canada-wide shared-cost program established by the federal government in an area of exclusive provincial jurisdiction so far as the province enacted its own program “compatible with the national interests” (Charlottetown Accord 1992). Somewhat relatedly, the Accord sought to enhance Canada’s social and economic union and strived to include a “social-economic charter” within Canada’s constitution (Charlottetown Accord 1992). On the social side, the proposed charter described the commitment of the federal and provincial governments to a comprehensive, universal, portable, publicly administered, and accessible health care system; reasonable access of all Canadian residents to housing, food, and other necessities; protecting workers’ right to organize and bargain collectively; and protecting, preserving, and sustaining the environment for present and future generations (Charlottetown Accord 1992). On the economic side, the proposed charter would recognize policy objectives underlying Canada’s economic union including working together to strengthen Canada’s economic union; the free movement of persons, goods, services, and capital; the goal of full employment; ensuring all Canadians have a reasonable standard of living; and ensuring sustainable and equitable development (Charlottetown Accord 1992).

Fourth, the Accord proposed several amendments relating to the rights of Aboriginal peoples. It proposed amending the constitution to recognize the right of Aboriginal peoples to self-government enshrining Aboriginal governments as a third order of government in Canada constitutionally similar to the federal and provincial governments (Charlottetown Accord 1992). Relatedly, the constitution would be amended to provide the legislative bodies of Aboriginal peoples access to the notwithstanding clause in the constitution and guarantee Aboriginal representation in the senate. Aboriginal representation in the House of Commons would not be guaranteed in the constitution but would be required to be pursued by the federal government (Charlottetown Accord 1992). In addition, the Accord also proposed requiring the consent of Aboriginal peoples to future constitutional amendments that involved their interests and amending the constitution to provide that nothing in the Charter of Rights and Freedom abrogates or derogates from Aboriginal, treaty or other rights of Aboriginal peoples (Charlottetown Accord 1992).

Fifth, and perhaps most contentiously, the Accord attempted to resolve long-standing debates surrounding the division of powers between the federal and provincial governments. It would have given the provinces exclusive jurisdiction over forestry, mining, tourism, housing, recreation, and cultural affairs, while the federal government would retain jurisdiction over national cultural bodies, such as the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board (Charlottetown Accord 1992). In addition, the federal government would be required to negotiate agreements with the provinces to harmonize policy in telecommunications, labor development and training, regional development, and immigration (Charlottetown Accord 1992). Moreover, the Accord would have limited two centralizing powers in Canada’s constitution. It would have repealed the federal power of disallowance and reservation which gives the federal government the power to overrule any provincial law within one year of its approval (Charlottetown Accord 1992). It would have also limited the scope of the federal declaratory power, which gives the federal government the power to declare a “work” to be for the general advantage of Canada and bring it under the jurisdiction of the federal government, to new works with the explicit consent of the provinces where the work is located (Charlottetown Accord 1992).

Although the Charlottetown Accord had the formal support of the federal government and all ten provincial governments and could have been legally enacted as a constitutional amendment, the federal government submitted the Accord to a national referendum in October 1992 still smarting from the criticism surrounding the Meech Lake Accord (Gall Charlottetown 2006a). British Columbia, Alberta, and Quebec had their own referendum laws, but British Columbia and Alberta choose to participate in the federal referendum. Quebec held its own provincial referendum (Gall Charlottetown 2006a). Nationally, 54.3% of the vote opposed the Accord while in Quebec 56.7% opposed the Accord (Gall Charlottetown 2006a). The Accord only won majority support in New Brunswick, Newfoundland, Prince Edward Island, the Northwest Territories, and by the narrowest margin of 50.1%, in Ontario (Gall Charlottetown 2006a). The Charlottetown Accord thus also failed to obtain Quebec’s consent for Canada’s constitution.

Quebec’s Second Referendum and the Secession Reference

After the failures of the Meech Lake and the Charlottetown Accords, the Parti Québécois won the 1994 Quebec election on the promise of holding another referendum on sovereignty (Whites 1999, 324; Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). On 30 October 1995, the second referendum was held and the question posed to voters was whether “…Quebec should become sovereign, after having made a formal offer to Canada for a new economic and political partnership…” (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). The referendum was defeated by a narrow margin of 50.6% to 49.4% (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a); Haljan 1998, 191).

Although the question posed to voters in the second referendum included the prospect of a continuing “economic and political partnership” with Canada, the question was somewhat stronger than the one posed in the first Quebec referendum on sovereignty for two reasons (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). First, whereas in the first referendum the Parti Québécois asked Quebec for a mandate to negotiate sovereignty-association with Canada, the second referendum implied that sovereignty would be declared regardless of whether Canada accepted Quebec’s offer of partnership (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). Second, whereas in the first referendum it was clear in the question itself that a second referendum would be held to approve the outcome of the sovereignty-association negotiations, the second referendum seemed to assume that the Quebec National Assembly had the authority to proclaim Quebec as a sovereign state as soon as the negotiations were complete or were judged fruitless (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). No second referendum would occur to approve the arrangements for Quebec’s separation (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). In essence, the second referendum was understood by many to proceed on the assumption that a unilateral declaration of independence would be legally effective to remove Quebec from Canada without any amendment to Canada’s constitution or without Canada’s approval to the terms of the arrangement for separation (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). It is not entirely clear that the Parti Québécois believed that a unilateral declaration of independence would be sufficient to effect secession without negotiation with the rest of Canada. Not only did the separatist movement beginning with René Lévesque always argue it would negotiate with the federal government, but the Parti Québécois appointed Lucien Bouchard as “Chief Negotiator” in 1976, suggesting they believed negotiation would follow a referendum victory (Phillips 1995; Doran 2001, 199–200). Nonetheless, the assumption that a unilateral declaration of independence was sufficient to effect secession formed the basis of a reference that ended up before the Supreme Court of Canada.

In the Secession Reference, the federal government posed three reference questions to the Supreme Court of Canada. First, the federal government asked whether Quebec’s National Assembly, legislature, or government could effect the secession of Quebec from Canada unilaterally under Canada’s constitution. A unanimous court answered no (Secession Reference 1998, para. 104). Second, the federal government asked whether Quebec’s National Assembly, legislature, or government could effect the secession of Quebec from Canada unilaterally under international law. A unanimous court also answered in the negative (Secession Reference 1998, para. 138). And third, the federal government asked in the event of a conflict between domestic and international law on Quebec’s right to effect unilateral secession from Canada, which would take precedence. The Supreme Court did not answer the question in light of its answers to the previous two questions (Secession Reference 1998, para. 147).

On the first issue, the Supreme Court of Canada held that Quebec could not unilaterally secede under Canada’s constitution without principled negotiations with other participants in the Confederation within Canada’s constitutional framework (Secession Reference 1998, para. 104). The Supreme Court reasoned as follows.

Secession is the effort of a group or section of a state to withdraw itself from the political and constitutional authority of that state to achieve a new territorial unit on the international plane (Secession Reference 1998, para. 83). It is both a legal and a political act (Secession Reference 1998, para. 83). In legal terms, secession would require an amendment to Canada’s constitution, to which Quebec is bound despite its refusal to join the patriation of the constitution and the adoption of the Charter of Rights and Freedom of 1982, which would necessarily require negotiation, because an act of secession “would purport to alter the governance of Canadian territory in a manner which undoubtedly is inconsistent with our current constitution arrangements” (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 47 and 83–84).

Canada’s constitution is an expression of the sovereignty of the people of the country (Secession Reference 1998, para. 85). It is made up of the written text, but also unwritten constitutional rules and principles – federalism, democracy, respect for minorities and constitutionalism and the rule of law – that inform and sustain the constitutional text and assist in the interpretation of the constitution and constitutional rights and obligations (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 32, 49 and 52). Democracy is an unwritten constitutional principle that may be given form through a referendum procedure (Secession Reference 1998, at paras. 32 and 87). Although the democratic principle would demand that considerable weight be given to the clear expression of the will of the people of Quebec to secede from Canada, democracy exists in the larger context of other constitutional principles (Secession Reference 1998, at paras. 87 and 149). A democratic vote by however strong a majority and the unwritten constitutional principle of democracy in Quebec could not have any legal effect on its own, nor could it push aside other the unwritten constitutional principles of federalism, the rule of law, the rights of individuals and minorities and the operation of democracy in the other provinces or in Canada as a whole (Secession Reference 1998, para. 151). As a result, while an expression of the democratic will of the people of Quebec could confer legitimacy on the efforts of the Quebec government to secede by legal constitutional means, Quebec could not, despite a clear referendum, purport to unilaterally invoke a right of self-determination to dictate the terms of a proposed secession to other parties in Canada’s federation (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 87 and 151).

As for the political aspect of secession, the Supreme Court was cautious in its guidance, but imposed a reciprocal obligation to negotiate on the other provinces and federal government. It held that should there be “a clear majority vote on a clear question” in favor of secession, this would confer legitimacy on the efforts of the Quebec government to initiate the constitutional amendment process to secede by legal means (Secession Reference 1998, para. 87). A clear repudiation of the people of Quebec of the existing constitutional order would impose a reciprocal obligation on the other provinces and federal government to negotiate constitutional changes to respond to that desire (Secession Reference 1998, para. 88). Although the negotiations do not need to lead to an agreement necessarily, the parties would be required to conduct negotiations consistent with constitutional principles and values considering the interests and rights of Quebec, other provinces, the federal government and minority groups (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 95–96). Notably, the Supreme Court did not define what “a clear majority on a clear question” means. Nor did the Court explain how the constitutional principles and values would govern negotiations. It left both of these questions for political actors to decide.

However, the Court did opine on the consequences of one side refusing to negotiate or failing to negotiate consistent with constitutional principles and values. Although the Court acknowledged that “[w]here there are legal rights there are remedies”, it explained that in some circumstances, including the issue of Quebec’s secession, the only appropriate recourse “lies through the workings of the political process rather than the courts” (Secession Reference 1998, para. 102). As such, the Supreme Court held that to the extent that a party breaches its constitutional duty to negotiate in accordance with constitutional principles and values, the party could face consequences at the international level (Secession Reference 1998, para. 103). For Quebec, its failure to negotiate in accordance with constitutional principles and values could undermine its claim to legitimacy as an independent state, a precondition for recognition by the international community (Secession Reference 1998, para. 103). For the federal government and other provincial governments, their failure to fulfil their obligation to negotiate in accordance with constitutional principles and values could undermine the legitimacy of their response to Quebec’s request for secession and the existing constitutional arrangement (Secession Reference 1998, para. 103).

It is worth noting that, on one hand, the Supreme Court concluded that secession is a legal as much as a political act, and thus there is a legal obligation to negotiate on the parties if there is a clear majority on a clear question in favor of secession. On the other hand, the Court failed to explore any legal remedies if one side refused to negotiate or failed to negotiate consistent with constitutional principles and values (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). However, given the political context underlying the Secession Reference, it is not particularly surprising that the Court treaded with caution and avoided opining on issues it did not need to consider to answer the reference questions before it (see also: Choudhry and Howse 2000, 166; Penney 2005, 240–246, 258–259).

On the second issue, Quebec’s right to unilaterally effect secession under international law, the Supreme Court held that Quebec had no right under international law to unilaterally secede (Secession Reference 1998, para. 138). Both parties in the reference, the Attorney General of Canada and amicus curiae on behalf of Quebec, acknowledged through their experts that it was clear that international law does not specifically grant component parts of a sovereign state the legal right to secede unilaterally from their parent state (Secession Reference 1998, para. 111). However, amicus curiae argued that the right to unilateral secession in international law existed on two grounds. It exists because it is not specifically prohibited and what is not specifically prohibited is inferentially permitted (Secession Reference 1998, para. 111). Alternatively, amicus curiae argued that states have an implied duty to recognize the legitimacy of secession brought about by the exercise of the well-established international legal right of “a people” to self-determination (Secession Reference 1998, para. 111).

The Supreme Court rejected the first proposition. It noted that while international law neither contains a right of unilateral secession nor the explicit denial of such a right, the denial is somewhat implicit in the exceptional circumstances required for secession to be permitted under the right of people to self-determination (Secession Reference 1998, para. 112). As for the second proposition, the Court accepted that the right of self-determination belongs to “peoples” and much of the Quebec population certainly shares characteristics of being “a people” (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 123 and 125). But, the Court held that the right of secession only arises under the principle of self-determination of people at international law where “a people” is governed as part of a colonial empire; where “a people” is oppressed, as for example, under foreign military occupation; or possibly where “a people” is denied meaningful access to government to pursue their political, economic, social and cultural development (Secession Reference 1998, para. 138).

In all three of these circumstances, “a people” is entitled to a right of secession under the principle of self-determination because they have been denied their ability to internally exert their right to self-determination (Secession Reference 1998, para. 138). All three of these circumstances are exceptional and in the Supreme Court’s view were “manifestly inapplicable to Quebec under existing conditions” (Secession Reference 1998, para. 138). Quebec did not meet the threshold of a colonial or an oppressed people (Secession Reference 1998, para. 154). Nor could it be said that Quebecers were being plausibly denied access to government to pursue their political, economic, social, and cultural development (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 136 and 154). Quebecers were equitably represented in Canada’s legislative, executive and judicial institutions (Secession Reference 1998, para. 136). The Supreme Court noted, that for close to 40 of the last 50 years, as at the time of the reference, the Prime Ministers of Canada have been Quebecers, Quebecers have held from time to time all the most important positions in the federal Cabinet and at the time, the Prime Minister of Canada, the Right Honourable Chief Justice of Canada and two other members of the Supreme Court, the Chief of Staff of the Canadian Armed Forces, and the Canadian ambassador to the United States and the Deputy Secretary-General of the United Nations were all Quebecers (Secession Reference 1998, para. 135). Quebecers occupied prominent positions within the government of Canada and were free to make political choices and pursue economic, social and cultural development within Quebec, across Canada and throughout the world (Secession Reference 1998, para. 136). As a result, the Court concluded that the “continuing failure to reach agreement on amendments to the Constitution, while a matter of concern, does not amount to a denial of self-determination” and based on the constitutional arrangements in place at the time of the reference “Quebecers [were not] in a disadvantaged position within the scope of the international law rule” (Secession Reference 1998, para. 137).

The Supreme Court did not close its eye to the possibility that de facto secession could take place without the required agreement or constitutional amendments (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 106 and 143). It recognized that Quebec could unilaterally effect its secession as a matter of fact (Secession Reference 1998, para. 106). Such a secession would be unconstitutional, but the Court noted that an unconstitutional secession could ultimately become effective if the seceding government achieved effective control of a territory and recognition by the international community (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 106–107). Recognition by the international community would likely be contingent on the legality and legitimacy of secession having regard to the conduct of Quebec and the rest of Canada (Secession Reference 1998, para. 155). But even then, such recognition would not provide retroactive jurisdiction for the act of secession at international law (Secession Reference 1998, para. 155). Secession would remain an illegal act, but it would acquire legal status if, as a matter of “empirical fact”, it came to be recognized on the international plane (Secession Reference 1998, para. 146).

Implications of the Secession Reference and the Right of External Self-Determination in International Law

In Canada, the immediate events that followed the Secession Reference was Parliament’s enactment of the Clarity Act (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a). The Clarity Act was intended to provide direction on the process by which it would be determined whether a referendum had yielded “a clear majority on a clear question” (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)). But more importantly, relying on the Supreme Court’s decision in Secession Reference, the Clarity Act “recognized” that under Canada’s constitution, there is no unilateral right of secession and that an amendment of the constitution would be required in order for a province to secede from Canada (Hogg 2007, §5.7(a)).

On the international stage, the Secession Reference led to two primary developments. First, it clarified and explained the state of international law concerning the scope of the right of external self-determination. Second, it provided valuable guidance on the importance of process legitimacy and the duty to negotiate between opposing factions in the context of secessionist attempts in representative and constitutional democracies, which has been relied on by countries around the world including Spain, Scotland, Italy, the European Union after Brexit, Sri Lanka and Ethiopia, to name a few (Delledonne and Martinico 2019; see also: Choudhry 2017, 1085–1092). The first development is the focus of this article and the discussion below.

Self-determination as a principle of international law was first considered in the Åland Islands case of 1921. At issue was whether the citizens of the Åland Islands could assert their right to self-determination to hold a plebiscite which would “leave no doubt as to the unanimous wish of the population for reunion with Sweden” and secession from Finland (Report of the Rapporteurs on Åland Islands 1921, 1). The Council of the League of Nations concluded that sovereignty of the Åland Islands belonged to Finland and resolved that Finland provide new guarantees on the language, culture and rights of the citizens of the Åland Islands (Åland Islands Case 1921, 699). The Council’s legal reasoning and commentary on self-determination is found in legal reports from the Commission of Jurists and Commission of Rapporteurs it appointed to advise it on the case (Åland Islands Case 1921, 699).

Both Commissions firmly rejected a positive international law right of external self-determination and the Commission of Rapporteurs did not even recognize self-determination as a rule of international law (Report of the ICJ on Åland Islands 1920; Report of the Rapporteurs on Åland Islands 1921, 3). The Commission of Jurists concluded “[p]ositive international law does not recognise the right of national groups, as such, to separate themselves from the State of which they form part by the simple expression of a wish, any more than it recognises the right of other States to claim such a separation. Generally speaking, the grant or refusal of the right to a portion of its population of determining its own political fate by plebiscite or by some other method, is exclusively, an attribute of the sovereignty of every State which is definitively constituted…” (Report of the ICJ on Åland Islands 1920). Similarly, the Commission of Rapporteurs concluded that the principle of self-determination “is not, properly speaking a rule of international law and the League of Nations has not entered it in its Covenant. … It is a principle of justice and of liberty, expressed by a vague and general formula which has given rise to the most varied interpretations and differences of opinion” (Report of the Rapporteurs on Åland Islands 1921, 3).

It was almost 25 years later, when the Charter of the United Nations came into force, that the international community officially recognized the principle of self-determination (Crawford 2019, 130). Article 1 of the UN Charter provides that the purposes of the United Nations is to “develop friendly relations among nations based on respect for the principle of equal rights and self-determination of peoples”. Article 55 of the UN Charter similarly provides that the United Nations will promote international economic and social cooperation “based on respect for the principle of equal rights and self-determination of peoples”.

Many saw the references to the principle of self-determination in the UN Charter as “merely hortatory” (Crawford 2019, 130). However, this concern was soon addressed when the international community not only adopted self-determination of all peoples but framed it as a right. In the Declaration on the Granting of Independence to Colonial Countries and Peoples (“Declaration”) adopted by the UN General Assembly in 1960, and referred to in a long series of resolutions since, the principle of self-determination is recognized as one of the obligations stemming from the UN Charter and the right of self-determination of all peoples – to freely determine their political status and freely pursue their economic, social and cultural development – is expressly acknowledged (Crawford 2019, 131). Recognition of self-determination as a right was further reinforced when it was included in Articles 1 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (“ICCPR”) and the International Covenant on International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights (“ICESCR”) in 1966 (Crawford 2019, 131).

At the time of the Declaration and the ICCPR and ICESCR, the main purpose of recognizing a right of self-determination of all peoples was to provide a meaningful vehicle for decolonization (Abel 2020). Indeed, between 1945 and 1970, 55 states gained independence through the application of the right of self-determination (Abel 2020; Namibia 1971, 75). In 1971, in its advisory opinion, Legal Consequences for States of the Continued Presence of South Africa in Namibia (South West Africa) notwithstanding Security Council Resolution 276 (1970), the International Court of Justice (“ICJ”) considered the legal consequences for other States of South Africa’s continued presence in Namibia. The ICJ confirmed the existence of a positive international law right of self-determination, found that the right to self-determination became applicable to non-self-governing territories, such as Namibia, and seemed to suggest that the very process of decolonization could be understood in terms of the application of the right to self-determination (Namibia 1971, 31). Decolonization was therefore one of the prime purposes, if not the prime purpose, of the advancement of a right to external self-determination (Abel 2020).

However, as territories under a colonial regime increasingly relied on the right of external self-determination to become post-colonial states, the international community became concerned with the ramifications of a right of external self-determination in a post-colonial world (Abel 2020; Buchanan 1992, 348; see also: Buchheit 1978, 117–121). The Commission of Rapporteurs had given voice to this concern several decades earlier in its report relating to the Åland Islands case. In explaining why an absolute rule allowing the minority population of a State to have a right of external self-determination was not possible, the Commission stated, “[t]o concede to minorities, either of language or religion, or to any fractions of a population the right to withdrawing from the community to which they belong, because it is their wish or good pleasure, would be to destroy order and stability within States and to inaugurate anarchy in international law; it would be to uphold a theory incompatible with the very idea of the State as a territorial and political unit” (Report of the Rapporteurs on Åland Islands 1921, 4). The Commission’s theoretical concern was starting to be seen in the international community as having potential to become reality. As a result, self-determination began to be referred to once more as a principle and the customary international law principle of uti possidetis further developed (Klabbers 2006, 195; Abel 2020).

Four years after Namibia, in 1975, the ICJ considered in its advisory opinion Western Sahara whether there were any legal ties between the Western Sahara territory and Morocco and/or the Mauritanian entity. The ICJ answered the question in the affirmative (Western Sahara 1975, 68–69). It found there had been legal ties of allegiance not establishing any ties of territorial sovereignty between both Morocco and the territory in question and the Mauritanian entity and the territory (Western Sahara 1975, 68). As such, none of the involved parties could establish title to the territory in question before the occupation of the territory in Spain but could point to having some legal ties with the territory. And in the absence of ties of territorial sovereignty, the ICJ held that there were no legal ties that could affect the application of self-determination with respect to the territory, in particular the application of “the principle of self-determination through the free and genuine express of the will of the peoples of the Territory” (Western Sahara 1975, 68).

Western Sahara is notable in the development of the understanding of the right of self-determination for two main reasons. First, the ICJ defines “the principle of self-determination” as “the need to pay regard to the freely expressed will of peoples” (Western Sahara 1975, 33). By omission, the ICJ excluded secession and other modalities of self-determination (Klabbers 2006, 194). Second, in Western Sahara, the ICJ repeatedly refers to self-determination as a principle not a right and ultimately defines “the principle of self-determination” (Western Sahara 1975, 33, 68). In effect, the ICJ conceived of self-determination as a procedural principle that has much to do with figuring out the “freely expressed will of people” but not necessarily attaching any substantive or enforceable rights to this freely expressed will (Klabbers 2006, 195 and 197).

At the same time, the international community’s concerns with the scope of the right of external self-determination could also be seen in the development of the customary international law principle of uti possidetis, a principle that was well-established in international law even before the time of the Åland Islands case but gained new attention in the 1980s. In the Case Concerning the Frontier Dispute, the ICJ considered the delimitation of the land frontier between Burkina Faso and Mali. In explaining the principle of uti possidetis, the ICJ held it is “a general principle, which is logically connected with the phenomenon of the obtaining of independence, whenever it occurs” (Frontier Dispute 1986, 565). Moreover, in laying out support for the principle of uti possidetis, the ICJ invoked the “principle of self-determination” (but also referring to it as a right in other places) to explain that stability has “induced” African states to consent to the maintenance of the “territorial status quo in Africa” and to “take account of it in the interpretation of the principle of self-determination of peoples” (Frontier Dispute 1986, 566–567).

Although, the Frontier Dispute is not a case about the right or principle of self-determination (the ICJ spoke about the right of self-determination only in passing), some scholars have taken it for implying two things with respect to self-determination. First, in Frontier Dispute as in Western Sahara, the ICJ construed self-determination as a principle rather than as a right (Klabbers 2006, 196). Second, the ICJ’s explanation of the principle of uti possidetis and self-determination shows that the Court viewed self-determination in territorial terms as something belonging to territories, not peoples (Klabbers 2006, 196).

The ICJ has also considered self-determination in three additional cases. In 1995, in East Timor (Portugal v. Australia), the ICJ held that the “principle of self-determinations of peoples has been recognized by the United Nations Charter and in the jurisprudence of the Court”, is one of the “essential principles of contemporary international law,” and has an erga omnes character (East Timor 1995, 102). All three of these propositions were confirmed in 2004 in the ICJ’s advisory opinion on the Legal Consequences of the Construction of a Wall in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, and, as recently as 2019, in the ICJ’s advisory opinion on the Legal Consequences of the Separation of the Chagos Archipelago from Mauritius in 1965 (Wall 2004, 171–172; Chagos Archipelago 2019, 136 and 139). Notably, in all these cases, the ICJ oscillated between referring to self-determination as a right and a principle.

The ICJ and international community’s preoccupation with limiting the right of self-determination is plain. As mentioned above, the concerns were first described in the Commission of Rapporteurs report relating to the Åland Islands case in the 1920s (Report of the Rapporteurs on Åland Islands 1921, 4). And the United Nations gave voice to this concern in 1992 in a report of the Secretary-General to the UN General Assembly and Security Council where it recognized the time of “absolute and exclusive sovereignty” has passed, but stated “[y]et if every ethnic, religious or linguistic group claimed statehood, there would be no limit to fragmentation, and peace, security and economic well-being for all would become ever more difficult to achieve” (Agenda for Peace 1992, 5).

In 1998, the Supreme Court of Canada considered the right of external self-determination in the Secession Reference in light of this international context and understanding of the right of self-determination. As a starting point, the Supreme Court used both principle and right to describe self-determination but seemed to conceptualize self-determination as a right but one so widely recognized in international treaties that it could also be considered a general principle of international law (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 113–114). But more importantly, as detailed above, the Supreme Court definitively identified two bases on which peoples could have a right to external self-determination: where a people is governed as part of a colonial empire and where a people is subject to alien subjugation, domination or exploitation (Secession Reference 1998, para. 154). And the Court recognized a third circumstance that “possibly” gives rise to a right of external self-determination – where a people is denied any meaningful exercise of its right to self-determination within the state of which it forms a part – known in the international community as “remedial secession”, a controversial concept in international law which came to the forefront in the Kosovo, Crimea and Palestine disputes (Secession Reference 1998, para. 154; Crawford 2019, 132).

Remedial secession began to seriously be considered and developed by scholars as a third basis of external self-determination in response to a wave of ethnic conflicts that affected several states in the early to mid-1990s (Meester 2010, 218; Tomuschat 2006, 42; Suksi 2005, 225; see also: Buchanan 1992, 354–356). Beyond the two broadly accepted situations of colonial domination and alien subjugation, some scholars created a new category of external self-determination, that of a last-resort remedy entailing a right to secede in situations involving denial of internal self-determination or massive human rights abuses (Meester 2010, 218).

Remedial secession was argued to be grounded in two sources (Meester 2010, 219). First, in the report of the Commission of Rapporteurs in the Åland Islands case. The Commission seemed to recognize that “[t]he separation of a minority from the State of which it forms a part and its incorporation in another State can only be considered as an altogether exceptional solution, a last resort when the State lacks either the will or the power to enact and apply just and effective governance” (Report of the Rapporteurs on Åland Islands 1921, 4). Second, scholars found support in the 1970 Declaration on Principles of International Law Concerning Friendly Relations and Co-operation among States in Accordance with the Charter of the United Nations. It states:

[A]ll peoples have the right freely to determine, without external interference, their political status and to pursue their economic, social and cultural development … Nothing in the foregoing paragraphs shall be construed as authorizing or encouraging any action which would dismember or impair, totally or in part, the territorial integrity or political unity of sovereign and independent States conducting themselves in compliance with the principles of equal rights and self-determination as described above and thus possessed of a government representing the whole people belonging to the territory without distinction as to race, creed or colour. (Declaration 1970, 8, 10–11)

In Secession Reference, in recognizing that where “a definable group is denied meaningful access to government to pursue their political, economic, social and cultural development”, an international law right of external self-determination could “possibly” exist but “remains unclear” the Supreme Court of Canada contemplated the existence of this third category of external self-determination that some scholars were arguing for (Secession Reference 1998, paras. 135, 138, and 154; Meester 2010, 220; Constantinides 2018, 67). However, it is fair to say that remedial secession was not and is not an established rule or principle of international law and the Secession Reference did not change international law in that regard (Crawford 1999, 114; 2006, 390; 2019, 132; Meester 2010, 220; Constantinides 2018, 67; Mar 2013, 79–108).

Remedial secession came to the forefront on the international stage in 2000s when Kosovo unilaterally declared independence from its parent state, Serbia, on 17 February 2008. The United Nations General Assembly asked the ICJ to render an advisory opinion on whether Kosovo’s unilateral declaration of independence was in accordance with international law. Several parties made submissions on the issues of remedial succession before the ICJ, but a majority of the Court found it unnecessary to consider the issue and refused to directly address it (Kosovo 2010, 438). However, 11 of 36 State submissions expressly recognized and supported remedial secession as established in international law and two judges also supported it in their separate opinions, and most of them cited the Supreme Court of Canada’s decision in Secession Reference (Meester 2010, 223).

In particular, Judge Abdulqawi Ahmed Yusuf was the most explicit in supporting remedial secession. He began with clearly stating that right of self-determination is one that is not “of mere historical interest nor has it exhausted its role in international law following the end of colonialism” (Kosovo 2010, 621). In the post-colonial context, the right of self-determination can operate to “pierce” the veil of sovereignty and confer certain internationally protected rights on peoples, groups and individuals who may be subject to “acts involving atrocities, persecution, discrimination and crimes against humanity committed inside a State” and imposes obligations on their own State as well as other States (Kosovo 2010, 620–621).

Judge Yusuf recognized that international law disfavours the fragmentation of existing states, promotes stability within the borders of states and does not grant every racially or ethnically distinct group within a state, even if it qualifies as a people for the purposes of self-determination, a right to unilateral secession simply because it wishes to create its own separate state (Kosovo 2010, 620 and 622). But he found that international law pays close attention to the plight of such groups where “the State not only denies them the exercise of their internal right of self-determination (as described above), but also subjects them to discrimination, persecution and egregious violations of human rights or humanitarian law” (Kosovo 2010, 622). Under such exceptional circumstances, the right of peoples to self-determination can support a claim to separate statehood if it meets the conditions prescribed by international law (Kosovo 2010, 622).

Judge Yusuf went on to note that in order to determine whether a specific situation constitutes an exceptional case that could justify a claim to external self-determination, certain criteria have to be considered, such as “such as the existence of discrimination against a people, its persecution due to its racial or ethnic characteristics, and the denial of autonomous political structures and access to government” (Kosovo 2010, 624). In addition, “[a]ll possible remedies for the realization of internal self-determination must be exhausted before the issue is removed from the domestic jurisdiction of the State” (Kosovo 2010, 624). Judge Yusuf’s opinion clearly lends support to remedial secession as a third basis of external self-determination the Supreme Court of Canada identified in Secession Reference.

Remedial secession also received support in the separate opinion of Judge Antônio A. Cançado Trindade. Unlike Judge Yusuf, Judge Trindade did not expressly adopt a right of remedial secession, but his opinion seemed to adopt much of the language pertaining to the concept (Meester 2010, 244). Judge Trindade began by accepting that the principle of self-determination has survived decolonization “to face nowadays new and violent manifestations of systematic oppression of peoples” (Kosovo 2010, 593). He went on to note:

No State can invoke territorial integrity in order to commit atrocities (such as the practices of torture, and ethnic cleansing, and massive forced displacement of the population), nor perpetrate them on the assumption of State sovereignty, nor commit atrocities and then rely on a claim of territorial integrity notwithstanding the sentiments and ineluctable resentments of the “people” or “population” victimized. … Such atrocities amount to an absurd reversal of the ends of the State, which was created and exists for human beings, and not vice-versa. (Kosovo 2010, 593)

Judge Trindade found that States have a duty to protect and empower their inhabitants, a duty that finds grounding in the 1970 Declaration on Friendly Relations and the 1993 Vienna Declaration and Programme of Action (Kosovo 2010, 594–595). He concluded that a government that incurs grave and systematic violations of human rights ceases to represent the people of a victimized population and fails to conduct itself in compliance with the principle of equal rights and self-determination of peoples (Kosovo 2010, 595).

Judge Trindade did not expressly accept that the right of self-determination of peoples incorporates remedial secession, but he appeared to accept the concept when he refers to the principle of self-determination arising from new situations of systematic oppression, subjugation and tyranny as taking precedence over the principle of territorial integrity (Meester 2010, 244). Indeed, when Judge Trindade concluded, regarding Kosovo, that “the entitlement to self-determination of the victimized population emerged, as the claim to territorial integrity could no longer be relied upon by the willing victimizers”, he appeared to give voice to the legitimacy of remedial secession (Kosovo 2010, 595).

Although remedial secession is not an established rule or principle of international law, the existence and legitimacy of it remains an open question (Crawford 2019, 232). In Canada, remedial secession certainly remains a possibility, but the situation in Quebec must rise to the Supreme Court’s threshold of the peoples of Quebec being denied any meaningful exercise of their right of self-determination within the country, an exceptionally high standard. In the Case of Lozidou v. Turkey, two judges of the European Court of Human Rights in a concurring opinion accepted that “peoples may also exercise a right to self-determination if their human rights are consistently and flagrantly violated or if they are without representation at all or are massively under-represented in an undemocratic and discriminatory way” (Lozidou 1996, 24). And in Kosovo, while the ICJ majority opinion refused to consider remedial secession and one judge expressly refused it, two judges accepted remedial secession, and maybe more would have if the ICJ would have considered the issue (Meester 2010, 252). Until then, remedial secession has and will continue to be raised as an argument in situations of self-determination and unilateral secession such as the Kosovo, Crimea and Palestine disputes and the issue remains open to debate.

The 1980 Quebec independence referendum was the first referendum in Quebec on whether Quebec should make a deal with Canada that would allow the province to have more control over its own laws, government, and trade agreements with other countries. The referendum was called by Quebec's Parti Québécois (PQ) government. The PQ wanted Quebec to be independent from Canada.

The province-wide referendum took place on Tuesday, May 20, 1980, and the proposal to request more independence from Canada was defeated. 59.56 percent of voters voted against the referendum question and 40.44 percent voted in favour of it.[1]

A second referendum on sovereignty in 1995 also failed, but by a smaller margin (50.58% to 49.42%).

Quebec, a province in the Canadian Confederation since its foundation in 1867, has always been the only province where the most commonly spoken language is French. Quebec has also historically been very connected to French culture and the Catholic Church, which was seen as the national church when the French colonists began to settle in what became Quebec. Many Quebecois people value their French identity and culture. In the early 1960s, Quebec went through a Quiet Revolution where politicians separated the role of the church from the role of government organisations in a process called secularisation. During this time period, political groups in the province began to identify as federalists (who wanted to be a part of a unified Canada) and sovereigntists (who wanted Quebec to become a sovereign nation state, separate from Canada).

A prominent sovereigntist was René Lévesque, who helped found the Parti Québécois (PQ) with like-minded separatists. The PQ proposed "sovereignty-association", a proposal for Quebec to be a sovereign nation-state while also sharing an economic partnership with Canada. The PQ had originally planned on declaring independence upon forming government, without putting it up for a vote in Quebec. Instead of doing this, the PQ chose to use a referendum so that the international community would be more likely to accept them as a truly independent nation.

The PQ won the 1976 election, beating the governing Quebec Liberals. The PQ campaign platform included a promise to hold a referendum on sovereignty-association during their first term. In government, the PQ created a number of popular reforms to long-term issues in the province, including francophone nationalist laws such as Bill 101, which reinforced French as the province's official language.

The PQ's beliefs were in conflict with the federal Liberal government of Pierre Elliot Trudeau, who did not agree with Quebec sovereignty. Instead, Trudeau urged Quebecers to seek empowerment at the federal level through reforms that provided for bilingualism and protection for individual rights. Trudeau was considered such a major opponent to Quebec sovereignty that Lévesque refused to call a referendum while Trudeau was the Prime Minister.

The Progressive Conservatives led by Joe Clark won a minority government in the May 22 1979 federal election. Clark's minority government made a point to not have the federal government be involved in the referendum, leaving the task of representing federalist voices to Claude Ryan, the new leader of the Quebec Liberal Party.

On June 21, 1979, Lévesque announced the promised referendum would occur in the spring of 1980, and that the question on the ballot would be announced before Christmas.

Lead-up to the Referendum Campaign [ change | change source ]

On November 1, 1979, the Quebec government released its constitutional proposal in a white paper titled Québec-Canada: A New Deal. The Québec Government Proposal for a New Partnership Between Equals: Sovereignty-Association.

A dramatic change occurred in Ottawa on December 11, 1979, when the Clark government unexpectedly lost a vote of confidence on a budget bill, forcing a federal election. Three days afterward, Trudeau announced his return as leader of the Liberals. Polls showed Clark losing handily.

The wording of the referendum question was a subject of debate between members of the Parti Québécois caucus. Some preferred a simple wording focused on Quebec becoming sovereign from Canada. Lévesque realised that sovereignty-association would require negotiations with the Government of Canada. Lévesque decided that the question would be written so that it gave the government of Quebec the power to negotiate with the Government of Canada, and that if the referendum passed, they would have a second referendum after making an agreement with the Canadian government so that Quebecers could approve the deal or vote against it. He also felt the safety of a second referendum would convince swing voters to vote "Yes."

A significant debate arose as to whether a "question" under the Referendum Act could have more than one sentence: the final compromise was to use semicolons.

The question announced on December 20, 1979 was:

"The Government of Quebec has made public its proposal to negotiate a new agreement with the rest of Canada, based on the equality of nations; this agreement would enable Quebec to acquire the exclusive power to make its laws, levy its taxes and establish relations abroad — in other words, sovereignty — and at the same time to maintain with Canada an economic association including a common currency; any change in political status resulting from these negotiations will only be implemented with popular approval through another referendum; on these terms, do you give the Government of Quebec the mandate to negotiate the proposed agreement between Quebec and Canada?"[note 1]

Lévesque, while noting its cumbersome nature, stated that it was transparent and could be easily understood.

Legislative debate [ change | change source ]

On February 18, 1980, the federal Liberals won a majority in the House of Commons, and Trudeau returned as Prime Minister. Trudeau announced Jean Chrétien as having responsibilities for the federal response to the referendum.

Television had recently been introduced to the Quebec National Assembly, and the legislative debate on the referendum question was scheduled for prime time live viewing on March 4, 1980. The debate lasted two weeks, and the result was a PQ success and a disaster for the provincial Liberals. The PQ Cabinet, coordinated by House Leader Claude Charron, provided detailed outlines of their files and the benefits they said sovereignty would provide them. The Liberals did not consider that the television audience would view their quick and taunting retorts about the referendum question to be insubstantial compared to the lengthy and detailed speeches of PQ members. The Liberals seemed to lack preparation and Ryan, unaware of the television cameras, was caught yawning on a few occasions during Liberal interventions.

Polls released after the debates showed the Yes and No side roughly even, with a majority among Francophone voters for the "Yes" side.

Brunch des Yvettes [ change | change source ]

Less helpful to the "Yes" campaign was a speech by former television presenter Lise Payette to a committee in Montreal, where she mocked what she viewed as the "No" side's complacency by imagining a person who planned on voting "No" as a Yvette - a docile schoolgirl from pre-Quiet Revolution schoolbooks. Payette also used this as a general theme in the legislature. Payette stated that Ryan wanted a Quebec full of "Yvettes" and that his wife, Madeline Ryan, was an Yvette. Lise Bissonnette, a popular journalist, responded to Payette's personal attack wrote a sarcastic editorial that compared Payette's television career with Mme Ryan's accomplishments in the public and private sector.

Payette apologized during the legislative debate, but the remark and the editorial sparked a movement. On March 30, a group of 1,700 women, including Madeline Ryan, held the brunch des Yvettes at the Château Frontenac in Quebec City. The movement grew until a rally at the Montreal Forum on April 7 when 14,000 women denounced the minister's declarations about women and manifested their support for the "No" side.

On April 15, Lévesque announced before the National Assembly the referendum would occur on May 20, 1980. The same day, on the opening of the House of Commons, Trudeau announced that the Government of Canada would not negotiate sovereignty-association under any circumstances, as he considered the question too vague and the Canadian government's authority too uncertain to do so. He also stated that the question was too vague to give Lévesque and the PQ any mandate to declare independence, making any result from a "Yes" vote impossible; in contrast, he offered that a "No" vote would lead to constitutional change. His position was supported by Clark and national NDP leader Ed Broadbent.

The "Yes" campaign was, in the initial stages, low key. It focused on gaining broad acceptance of sovereignty-association through specialized "regroupments" that would be presented with special certificates at ceremonies led by Lévesque and other cabinet ministers. The regroupments were seen as an attempt to show broad support for the movement and create conversations at the ground level, however, the attempt to create them in some heavily Federalist professions, such as lawyers, prompted a severe backlash.

The "No" campaign, led by Ryan, was run as a traditional election campaign, with Ryan campaigning during the day and making speeches in local hockey arenas across rural Quebec.

Controversially, the Canadian government became involved on its own accord in the referendum despite the provisions of the provincial Referendum Act, which tightly restricted all campaigning to the designated "Yes" and "No" committees with set budgets. Canadian government politicians made appearances coordinated by Minister of Justice Jean Chrétien and Marc Lalonde, mainly speculating on the economic uncertainty a "Yes" vote could bring. Chrétien argued that prominent PQ member Claude Morin would sacrifice Canada's oil and national gas price to drive in an ambassadors' Cadillac. Lalonde argued that old age pensions were directly threatened by a "Yes" vote. Though initially reluctant, Ryan started to accept and welcome the Canadian government's help, and continued to speak across Quebec.

The referendum prompted an unheard-of political mobilization, and the campaign was seen as a traumatic event in Quebec, as the hard choice between "Yes" and "No" shattered the nationalist consensus that had existed since the Quiet Revolution.

Trudeau at Paul Sauvé Arena [ change | change source ]

On May 14, six days before the vote, Trudeau made his final appearance at a packed Paul Sauvé Arena, where the PQ had celebrated their victory in 1976. Trudeau attacked the "Yes" campaign for not asking a clear question, and stated that a "Yes" vote was a dead end, given that the rest of Canada was not bound by the question and that it was too vague to pursue independence if negotiations were refused.

Trudeau then stated that he would interpret a vote for the "No" as a mandate to renew federalism and change the constitution, putting his MPs' seats on the line if he were to fail to keep this promise. Addressing himself to Canadians outside Quebec on behalf of his MPs, Trudeau challenged English Canada that change would have to occur and that the referendum could not be interpreted as an endorsement of the status quo.

After this Trudeau hit an emotional high note, invoking a remark by Lévesque days earlier that he was showing his "Elliott" side during the campaign. Trudeau detailed the story of his parents, who had both had many ancestors in Quebec, and remarked that his full name was both a Québécois and a Canadian name. Trudeau then began to list members of the Parti Québécois who had Irish or English last names. The riposte brought the crowd to an uproar, and Trudeau exited to chants of "Elliott."

The speech, which prompted Morin to wonder if his mind was changed, was seen as the death knell of the "Yes" camp, despite Lévesque's attempts to cast doubt over Trudeau's words.

Immediate aftermath [ change | change source ]

After the lopsided defeat, a visibly emotional Lévesque addressed his supporters, many of whom were shown on screen in tears at the result. Lévesque began his concession speech by saying "My dear friends, if I understand you correctly, you're saying: 'until next time.'" In the speech, he called the Canadian government's involvement in the campaign "scandalously immoral," and emphasized that the result must be accepted and that it was now the Canadian government's responsibility to provide the changes to the constitution that Trudeau had promised. Lévesque ended by asking the audience to sing "Gens du Pays" for him, as he did not have any voice left.

Claude Ryan's speech was later in the evening. After refusing to let Jean Chrétien use the microphone to address those gathered, he proceeded to demand an election be called and listed every riding that had voted for the "No" side. The speech was generally seen as callous and harsh, especially after the emotional crowd scenes broadcast during Lévesque's speech. Trudeau addressed the country afterward with a more conciliatory tone, emphasizing the need for unity after the hurt feelings and strained friendships that had been caused by the referendum. The next morning, Chrétien was tasked with creating a provincial consensus.

After the referendum, Trudeau acted upon his promise by calling together the provincial premiers in a first ministers' conference. The meeting showed signs of deadlock, and Lévesque surprised observers by uniting with the dissident premiers, who warmly received his decentralist views. Facing a lack of cooperation from the premiers, Trudeau then announced his intention to unilaterally patriate the constitution from the United Kingdom and have a charter of rights and constitutional amending formula approved by national referendum.

In the meantime, there was a provincial election in Quebec. Despite a brief post-referendum malaise, the PQ easily defeated Ryan's Liberals in the 1981 provincial election, campaigning both on their governing record and against Trudeau's intentions. Notably, the PQ did not promise to hold a second referendum.

With regards to Trudeau's plans to unilaterally patriate and change the constitution, the newly re-elected Lévesque, who had initially argued for the incorporation of a Quebec veto into the new constitution, agreed with eight other premiers (the Gang of Eight) to a proposal that would not allow Quebec a veto, but would permit "opting out" of certain federal endeavours with compensation.

The federal government, still interested in proceeding unilaterally, sought an opinion on whether it was legally entitled to do so from the Supreme Court of Canada. The Supreme Court ruled that any constitutional changes, including patriation of the constitution, could be made unilaterally under the letter of the law, but, by non-binding convention, "a substantial degree of provincial consent was required".

The Supreme Court's decision prompted a final meeting among the first ministers. Lévesque abandoned the Gang of Eight and opted to join Trudeau in advocating immediate patriation with the promise of a future referendum on the other matters. The other premiers, loath to be seen arguing against the charter of rights that was included in Trudeau's proposed constitutional changes, formulated a compromise proposal with Jean Chrétien that was acceptable to the Canadian government. The compromise came during the Kitchen Meeting, which took place after Lévesque had left for the evening. In Quebec, that night has sometimes been called the "Night of the Long Knives".

As a result of the compromise between the premiers (other than Lévesque) and the federal government, the government partiated the Canadian constitution in the Constitution Act, 1982 without support from Lévesque or Quebec's National Assembly. The result was a shattering defeat for the PQ, especially after the Quebec government's loss in its Quebec Veto Reference case. The National Assembly of Quebec, compared to its position in 1976, actually lost power under Lévesque and the PQ.

Historical debate would centre on whether Trudeau's advocacy and agreement on patriation were in accord with or in contravention of his commitments made in his speech at the Paul Sauvé Arena. Trudeau defended his actions by stating he had kept his promise to deliver a new constitution that resided entirely within Canada and an embedded Charter of Rights. Quebec nationalists argue that this is an overly literal view of his words and that, in context to a Québécois audience, Trudeau had promised that Quebec would be given a status in accordance with a decentralized view of federalism, or his MPs would resign.

In 1984, Brian Mulroney led the Progressive Conservatives to victory nationally, having committed during the campaign to try to find a way to accommodate Quebec's objections to the constitution. Lévesque pledged to take the risk of trying to work towards a deal with Mulroney. This led to a split in the PQ and subsequently Lévesque's resignation from politics in 1985. After the PQ defeat by the Liberals of Robert Bourassa, the Mulroney government began negotiations with Quebec to find a deal that would be acceptable to all provinces. The 1987 Meech Lake Accord and the 1992 Charlottetown Accord, despite receiving unanimous consent among the provincial premiers, each failed in dramatic public fashion, reviving the sovereignty movement.

The PQ returned to office, led by hard-line separatist and former Finance Minister Jacques Parizeau, in 1994. Parizeau called a second sovereignty referendum of 1995, which featured a more direct question. That referendum failed by a margin of less than 0.6%.

Sovereignty-Association

|

‘Sovereignty-association’ is one manifestation of Quebec separatism. It calls for political independence and an ongoing economic partnership with Canada. Conceptualized by René Lévesque, ‘sovereignty-association’ was the centrepiece of the Parti Québécois' (PQ) secessionist platform during the years Lévesque led the party (1968-85). ‘Sovereignty-association’ was intended to increase the strength of the independence movement by calming fears that a political divorce from Canada would deliver tough economic times to the people of Quebec. Lévesque's political instincts were shrewd. In the 1970s Quebec public opinion polls consistently reported that people were more likely to support political independence if it included maintaining an economic partnership with Canada.

A mandate to negotiate ‘sovereignty-association’ was the subject of the 1980 Quebec referendum, the first Quebec referendum on sovereignty. Premier Lévesque sought majority support from Quebec voters to negotiate the terms of ‘sovereignty-association’ with Canada. The results of those negotiations would be put to the public in a second referendum.

In a 1979 position paper the PQ stated that sovereignty-association should include free trade between Canada and Quebec, common tariffs against imports, and a common currency. New joint Quebec-Canada political institutions were proposed to govern these economic arrangements. Various English Canadian political leaders declared that they would not negotiate an economic association with a sovereign Quebec. These declarations generally are conceded to have contributed to the decisive defeat the separatists suffered in the 1980 referendum.

In the 1990s, the idea that an economic association with Canada must be a condition of Quebec independence waned in popularity. The question posed in the 1995 referendum only stipulated that Quebec should offer a new economic and political partnership to Canada before declaring independence. Canada's acceptance was not a prerequisite for sovereignty. Unlike in 1980, the separatists lost this second referendum by the narrowest of margins (50.6 percent to 49.4 percent) (see secession).
